media_caption: Juru-Pakal, CCP Dance Workshop Company, CCP, Manila, 1971
media_credit: Photo from Manila Chronicle Photo Collection, courtesy of Lopez Museum
text_description: Juru-Pakal, a modern ballet in one act based on a Mindanao epic, is choreographed by Eddie Elejar and is performed by the CCP Dance Workshop Company, later Ballet Philippines, at the CCP. (Photo from Manila Chronicle Photo Collection and Lopez Museum)

media_caption: Denisa Reyes’s For the Gods, Ballet Philippines, CCP, Manila, 1985
text_description: For the Gods, a modern dance in one act inspired by the Bukidnon thanksgiving ritual dugso, is choreographed by Denisa Reyes for Ballet Philippines at the CCP. (Photo from Ballet Philippines Collection)

media_caption: Jota caviteña by the Bayanihan Philippine Dance Company, ca 1970
text_description: Spanish folk song dances like the fandango and jota are disseminated throughout the 18th century. Both are characterized by couple dancing and the use of castanets and guitars. Photo: Jota Caviteña as performed by the Bayanihan Dance Company, ca 1970. (Philippine Dance: Mainstream and Crosscurrents)

media_caption: Rigodon de honor at Malacañan with Commonwealth President Manuel L. Quezon and guests, 1938
media_credit: Photo from Foto News 1938, Eli Guieb III Collection
text_description: English country dance (contredanse) becomes fashionable in French courts; along with gavotte, and rigaudon, it spreads throughout Europe. Photo: Rigodon de Honor at Malacañan with Commonwealth President Manuel L. Quezon and guests, 1938. (Foto News 1938, Eli Guieb III Collection)

media_caption: UST Salinggawi, 2015
text_description: UST Salinggawi wins the UAAP Cheerdance Competition for five consecutive years since 2002. They will be defeated the following year by UP PEP Squad, its closest rival. Photo: UST Salinggawi, 2015 (Efigenio Toledo IV)

media_caption: Alice Reyes’s Amada, CCP, Manila, 1978
media_credit: Photo by Rudy Vidad, Ballet Philippines Collection
text_description: The Alice Reyes and Modern Dance Company performs Amada at CCP. (Photo by Rudy Vidad, Ballet Philippines Collection)

media_caption: First significant batch of Filipino dancers, including Leonor Orosa-Goquingco and Rosalia Merino-Santos, taught by Luva Adameit during the American period
article_title: Dance 1927 Cosmopolitan Ballet and Dancing School
text_description: Polish choreographer Luva Adameit aka Madame Adameit (1895-48) establishes the Cosmopolitan Ballet and Dancing School in Manila. Her students include Leonor Orosa, Remedios de Oteyza, Rosalia Merino, Inday Gaston, Joji Felix, Chloe Cruz, Pacita Madrigal, and Fely Franquelli. (Photo from Rosalia Merino-Santos Collection)

media_caption: Trudl Dubsky-Zipper in “Mountain King’s Daughter” from Peer Gynt Suite
text_description: Viennese dancer-teacher-choreographer Trudl Dubsky (in photo) teaches modern dance at the Academy of Music and foreign dances at the University of the Philippines. (Photo from Steve Villaruz Collection)

The inauguration is greeted by a floor-show with Carmen “Miami” Salvador, the Philippines’ Fred Astaire Bayani Casimiro, and the Diaz Sisters at the Santa Ana Cabaret; and high society balls of the Club Filipino, Kahirup, and Mancomunidad Pampangueña ballroom dances.

media_caption: Leonor Orosa-Goquingco’s “Morolandia,” part of Filipinescas: Philippine Life, Legend and Lore in Dance, Paris, 1961
text_description: Leonor Orosa-Goquingco produces her significant work, Filipinescas: Philippine Life, Legend and Lore in Dance, which consolidates some of her earlier works as far back as 1938 such as “Vinta” and “Morolandia” (pictured). (Photo from Leonor Orosa-Goquingco Collection)

media_caption: Mir-i-nisa, Dance Theater Philippines, CCP, Manila, 1969
text_description: Mir-i-nisa is the first Filipino ballet presented during the inaugural season of the CCP, choreographed by Julie Borromeo and Felicitas Layag-Radaic. (CCP Collection)

media_caption: Street dance during the Kasaysayan ng Lahi parade, CCP, Manila, 1974
text_description: The highlight of the inauguration of Folk Arts Theater is a spectacular street parade with streetdancing titled Kasaysayan ng Lahi. (Photo from National Media Production Center)

media_caption: Nonong Pedero and Bienvenido Lumbera’s Tales of the Manuvu, Ballet Philippines, CCP, 1977
text_description: Tales of the Manuvu, a rock opera ballet in five parts based on indigenous myths and tales is staged by Alice Reyes at the CCP with script and libretto by Bienvenido Lumbera and music by Nonong Pedero and the Afterbirth. (Photo from Nicanor G. Tiongson Collection)
Bayanihan performs at Brussels Universal Exposition and wins over 13 national dance groups. The Ed Sullivan Show features the Bayanihan telecast with some 40 million television viewers.

media_caption: Discorama, ca 1970
text_description: Disco dancing becomes a craze and disco clubs proliferate in Metro Manila and other key cities of the country. Disco dancing also dominates television variety shows such as Discorama (pictured). (Photo from GMA Network)

media_caption: UP Peryante in a kilos-awit performance, Liwasang Bonifacio, Manila, 1983
text_description: UP Peryante (in photo) and Patatag, composed of students and young cultural activists, popularize the kilos-awit, a street performance with singing and body movements. The creative protest action is performed in venues like the business district of Makati, Liwasang Bonifacio, and Mendiola Bridge. (Photo from Susan Quimpo)

media_caption: Alleluia Panis and Joey Maliga of Kulintang Arts Ensemble
text_description: In San Francisco, USA, Kulintang Arts, Inc. popularly known as Kularts, is established by Robert L. Henry, Marcella Pabros, and Alleluia Panis (in photo, with Joey Maliga) as its artistic director, to support the creation of works inspired by indigenous Philippine traditions. (Photo from Alleluia Panis)

media_caption: Itim Asu, Alice Reyes and Modern Dance Company, CCP, Manila, 1970
media_credit: Photo by Rudy Vidad, Ballet Philippines Collection
text_description: Itim Asu is choreographed by Alice Reyes based on Virginia Moreno’s play The Onyx Wolf also at the CCP. (Photo by Rudy Vidad, Ballet Philippines Collection)

media_caption: Tatlong Kuwento ni Lola Basyang, Ballet Manila, Aliw Theater, Manila, 2015
text_description: Ballet Manila presents Tatlong Kwento ni Lola Basyang with choreography by Osias Barroso, Lisa Macuja-Elizalde, and Tony Fabella. (Photo by Erica Jacinto)

media_caption: Tony Fabella’s Limang Dipa, modern ballet by Dance Theater Philippines, Pasig City, 1981
text_description: Limang Dipa, a choreography by Tony Fabella in modern ballet and jazz with original Filipino compositions, is premiered by Dance Theater Philippines at the Meralco Theater. (Photo from CCP)

media_caption: A couple dancing the binanog, Iloilo City, 2016
text_description: The Historia de las Islas e Indios de Bisayas by Jesuit missionary Francisco Ignacio de Alcina describes Visayan dances such as a courtship dance imitating the mating of birds like the binanog, here performed by a couple in Iloilo City, 2016. (Photo by Bombette Golez Marin).

media_caption: Dinuy-a, an Ifugao ceremonial dance, 2013
text_description: Ritual dancing with animal sacrifice called cañao and spontaneous group dancing such as dinuyya are primeval dances of the Ifugao. Photo: A dinuyya performance in 2013. (Nawe Geofrey)

media_caption: Diyandi Festival, 2009
text_description: In Iligan, Mayor Camilo Cabili appoints Felicidad Actub to organize a diyandi dance group from the traditional culture bearers who perform the religious ritual in honor of San Miguel every 29th of September. The religious feast will be transformed into a festival with street dancing in 2004. Photo: Diyandi Festival, 2009 (Rev Adan)

media_caption: A version of the escotis, Bayanihan Philippine Dance Company, Manila, ca 1970
text_description: Maestro Appiani, an Italian choreographer and dance teacher, forms the Compañia Infantil de Baile to perform in theaters like the Teatro de Binondo. For over a decade, he teaches ballroom dancing routines, among them quadrilles like the gavotte and rigodon, the redova, and the schottische, performed here by a dancer from the Bayanihan Dance Company, ca 1970. (Photo from Bayanihan Dance Company Collection)

media_caption: Sakuting by the Philippine Baranggay Folk Dance Troupe
article_title: Dance 1958 Philippine Baranggay Folk Dance Troupe
text_description: The Philippine Baranggay Folk Dance Troupe (in photo) organized by Paz Cielo A. Belmonte (1916-2013) performs at the first Philippine Floating Exposition in Southeast Asian countries. (Mario Feir Filipiniana Library)

media_caption: Locking, a hip-hop dance style, Manila, 2008
text_description: Hip-hop dancing captivates the youth and MTV Asia produces a music video featuring the elements of hip-hop. (Photo by Niccolo Cosme)

media_caption: Ligaya Fernando Amilbangsa performing her choreography of langka budjang (female martial dance) using a fan, Seoul, Korea, 1988
text_description: The Tausug and Sama perform the langka dances, which resemble the ancient martial arts in Indonesia. Both are based on mastery of the self and alignment with the spiritual dimension.
Ligaya F. Amilbangsa premieres Paglami-lami (Celebration) at the CCP, dedicated to Leonor Orosa-Goquingco who was born in Sulu.

media_caption: Sama women performing the igal or pangalay, Busbus, Jolo, 1976
text_description: Pangalay or igal, a pre-Islamic and pre-Christian dance form similar to dance traditions in Cambodia, Indonesia, and other Asian countries, is performed by natives of the Sulu Archipelago. Photo: Sama women performing the pangalay in Jolo,1976. (Joseph Fortin, CCP Collection)
The rigodon de honor is performed in Malacañan with the new national officials.

media_caption: Sagayan, FEU Dance Troupe, ca 1990
text_description: Relatedly, the Maguindanaw and the Maranaw prepare for battle through a sacred war dance, the sagayan, inspired by the epic hero Bantugan. Photo: FEU Dance Troups performing the sagayan, ca 1990 (Nicanor G. Tiongson)

media_caption: Subli performers in Bauan, Batangas, 1990
text_description: In celebration of Batangas City Foundation Day, the Cultural Affairs Board of Batangas City launches the annual Sublian Festival to encourage school and community groups to learn the dances, songs, and prayers from the traditional manunubli and to perform 10-minute excerpts in the annual competition. (Photo from CCP)

media_caption: Dance number from Dance Time with Chito, ca 1970
text_description: Channel 7 airs Dancetime with Chito (in photo). The hit TV show pioneers in TV dancing, featuring Chito Feliciano and his group performing ballroom dances, such as chacha, rhumba, and tango. (Photo from GMA Network)

media_caption: Panagbenga Festival, 2016
text_description: The Baguio Flower Festival, also known as the Panagbenga, begins as an annual festival to highlight Baguio’s flower industry and Cordillera culture. Indigenous performances such as male gangsa-playing and female banga or pot dance are part of the festival. Pictured: Panagbenga Festival, 2016 (Photo by Eduardo Rabaya Castro)

media_caption: Francisca Reyes-Aquino, 1962 Ramon Magsaysay awardee for government service
media_credit: Photo from Lola Kikay: Life and Works of Francisca Reyes-Aquino, Francisca Reyes- Aquino Memorial Foundation, 2007
text_description: Francisca Reyes-Aquino receives the Ramon Magsaysay Award for government service as “teacher and researcher of traditional performing arts who facilitated a creative national expression of Filipino culture.” (Photo from Lola Kikay: Life and Works of Francisca Reyes-Aquino, Francisca Reyes- Aquino Memorial Foundation, 2007)

media_caption: National Artist for Dance Lucrecia Reyes-Urtula, 1988
text_description: Lucrecia Reyes-Urtula is proclaimed National Artist for Dance. (Photo from CCP)

media_caption: National Artist Awardee Leonor Orosa-Goquingco, 1976
text_description: Leonor Orosa-Goquingco is proclaimed as National Artist for Dance. (Photo from Steve Villaruz Collection)

media_caption: Alice Reyes, 2014
text_description: Alice Reyes is proclaimed National Artist for Dance but conferment happens two years after.

media_caption: Kalinga suite by the Ramon Obusan Folkloric Group, Ugat Ugnayan, CCP, Manila, 2013
text_description: Philippine Ballet Theatre and Ramon Obusan Folkloric Group (in photo) become resident companies of the CCP, receiving some funding and a performance venue grant at the Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo. Ballet Philippines and Bayanihan continue as CCP resident companies. (Photo from CCP)
Trudl Dubsky-Zipper choreographs and designs A Midsummer Night’s Dream which premieres at the Rizal Memorial Coliseum.

media_caption: Francisca Aquino and husband Ramon Tolentino Jr, both standing, with the UP Folk Song and Dance Club, 1934
text_description: · UP President Bocobo commissions Francisca Reyes-Tolentino, Antonino Bunevantura, and Ramon Tolentino to document folk dances, songs, music, music instruments, and other related artistic and cultural expressions.

media_caption: Pangalay: Traditional Dances and Related Folk Artistic Expressions, publication on dance research by Ligaya Fernando Amilbangsa, 1983
media_credit: Photo from Ligaya Fernando Amilbangsa and Filipinas Foundation for the Ministry of Muslim Affairs
text_description: Ligaya F. Amilbangsa’s Pangalay: Traditional Dances and Related Folk Artistic Expressions is published. (Photo from Ligaya Fernando Amilbangsa and Filipinas Foundation for the Ministry of Muslim Affairs)

media_caption: Philippine Dance: Mainstream and Crosscurrents by Reynaldo G. Alejandro. Vera-Reyes, 1978
text_description: Philippine Dance: Mainstream and Crosscurrents by Reynaldo G. Alejandro is published. (Photo from Vera-Reyes, Inc)

media_caption: Andres KKK, Philippine Ballet Theatre, CCP, Manila, 1996
text_description: Andres KKK, choreographed by Gener Caringal for Philippine Ballet Theatre (PBT), celebrates the centennial of the 1896 revolution about the heroism and fall of Andres Bonifacio. (Photo from PBT Collection)

media_caption: Diablos, PETA, Dulaang Rajah Sulayman, 1989
text_description: Diablos, an experimental dance drama based on a Bagobo folktale is choreographed by Denisa Reyes, and is premiered by PETA and CCP at Dulaang Raha Sulayman, Fort Santiago, Manila. The story is about a woman about to give birth in a town suffering the ravages of war. (Photo from PETA Library and Archives)

media_caption: Indios Bravos, Airdance, Quezon City, 2004
text_description: Airdance Theatre Inc is founded by dancers from Powerdance. Productions include Indios Bravos, 2004, Love Potion No. 9, 2007, and Adarna, 2011. (Photo from Airdance Collection)

media_caption: Kayaw, Larawan Dancing Group, CCP, Manila, 1974
text_description: Ramon Obusan premieres Kayaw at the CCP. The performance features the Larawan Dancing Group with indigenous Kalinga performers. (Photo from Ramon A. Obusan)

media_caption: La Lampara, CCP Dance Company, CCP, Manila, 1980
text_description: Jose Rizal’s second novel, El Filibusterismo, is published in Ghent, Belgium. The novel will fire up the imagination of future choreographers, as in Basilio's La Lampara and Morales’s Simoun. (Photo from Steve Villaruz Collection)

media_caption: 2014 restaging of La Revolucion Filipina
text_description: La Revolucion Filipina is choreographed by Agnes Locsin for Ballet Philippines, narrating the conflicts between Apolinario Mabini and Emilio Aguinaldo during the period of the Malolos Republic. Shown is the 2014 restaging. (Photo from CCP) .

media_caption: Anita Kane’s Mariang Makiling, Ateneo de Manila Auditorium, Manila, 1939
text_description: Teacher-choreographer Anita Kane produces the first full-length ballet Mariang Makiling to original music by Ramon Tapales with Elisa Robles in the title role. It is the first to use a local legend and a composition originally created for ballet. (Photo from UP Archives)

media_caption: Basilio’s Misa Filipina, Manila, 1984
text_description: To dramatize the assassination of Ninoy Aquino Jr in 1983, Misa Filipina, a ballet for Holy Mass, is choreographed and designed by Basilio aka Basilio Esteban Villaruz at the Manila Cathedral and at Puerta Real, Intramuros, Manila, with dancers from Dance Theater Philippines. (Photo from Steve Villaruz Collection)

media_caption: “Asalto for Maria,” part of Noli Dance Suite, CCP, Manila, 2011
text_description: The Noli Dance Suite, a modern ballet in one act by Leonor Orosa-Goquingco inspired by the writing of Jose Rizal, premieres at the GSP Auditorium. Photo: 2011 performance of Noli Dance Suite at the CCP. (Photo by Niki de los Reyes-Torres)

Of Cocks and Kings, a dance drama in one act by Rosalia Merino-Santos based on a short story by Alejandro R. Roces with music by Lucrecia R. Kasilag, is performed by the FEU Modern Experimental Dance Workshop at the Far Eastern University Auditorium.

media_caption: One Ton Pinay, New York City, USA, 1979
text_description: In New York, Denisa Reyes premieres One Ton Pinay, a solo dance in three parts presented in the concert titled Neo-Filipino. The name “Neo-Filipino” eventually becomes the title of a choreographic series under Reyes’s direction showcasing experimental works of new choreographers. (Photo from CCP)
Rama, Hari premieres at CCP, a rock opera ballet based on the Ramayana choreographed by Alice Reyes, with music by Ryan Cayabyab, and libretto by Bienvenido Lumbera.

media_caption: Ballet Philippines restaging of Sisa at the CCP, 1978
text_description: Sisa, a modern dance in one act, is choreographed by Cora Generoso-Iñigo based on a play by Amelia Lapeña-Bonifacio, performed by the UP Filipiniana Dance Group at UP Diliman. Photo: Ballet Philippines restaging of Sisa at the CCP, 1978. (Mario Pamintuan)

media_caption: Myra Beltran in Frida, 2007
text_description: Dance Forum, founded in 1995 by Myra Beltran (in photo), opens its studio-theater in Quezon City which becomes a venue for dancers and new choreographers. Works from 1997-2000 include Fragile Circle, Quartet for the End of Time, and Bachianas Brasilieras no. 1. (Photo from Myra Beltran)

media_caption: Pangalay ha patong performed by members of the Ingat Kapandayan Artist Center of Notre Dame of Jolo College, 2013
text_description: Natives of the Sulu Archipelago perform pangalay postures and gestures, especially of arms and hands, which are similar to those inscribed on the walls of Angkor Wat. Photo: Pangalay ha patong performed by Ingat Kapandayan Artist Center of Notre Dame of Jolo College, 2013. (Pinoy Adventurista)

media_caption: Habanera de Jovencita by the Bayanihan Philippine Dance Company, ca 1970
media_credit: Photo from Bayanihan Philippine Dance Company Collection
text_description: Habanera, 19th century song dance from Havana Cuba, spreads to Hispanic countries. Photo: Habanera de Jovencita by the Bayanihan Dance Company, ca 1970 (Bayanihan Dance Company Collection)

media_caption: Portrait of Praxedes Julia Fernandez aka Yeyeng, star of the Spanish zarzuela in the 1890s
text_description: Praxedes “Yeyeng” Fernandez dances a cancan number in a zarzuelita titled Pascual Bailon eliciting strong reactions, positive from the audience and negative from the church. (Photo from La Ilustracion Filipina, CCP Collection)

media_caption: La Revolucion Filipina, Ballet Philippines, CCP, Manila, 2014
text_description: Quadrilles are performed in the Malolos convent, which served as Aguinaldo’s Palacio Presidencial, in the evening of Jan 23. The Malolos Republic and the conflicts within the leadership of the Philippine Revolution after the death of Bonifacio will inspire Agnes Locin's La Revolucion Filipina. (Photo from CCP Collection)

media_caption: The cakewalk scene, Filipinas para los Filipinos, Manila, 1905
text_description: Severino Reyes’s Filipinas para los Filipinos features the cakewalk among other dances brought in during the early years of American colonization. (Photo from CCP)

media_caption: A bodabil chorus number, Manila Grand Opera House, ca 1950
text_description: The bodabil expands to include the “drama-skit” and is renamed stage show. Photo: A bodabil chorus number at the Manila Grand Opera House, ca 1950.

Lou Borromeo’s bodabil production titled Borromeo’s Follies, featuring dancing girls, singers, musicians, comedians, and magicians, is launched at the Manila Carnival’s national fair at the Olympic Stadium. (Photo from Alex R. Castro Collection)

media_caption: The National Artists for Dance: Francisca Reyes-Aquino, 1972
article_title: Dance 1927 Philippine Folk Dances and Games
text_description: Francisca “Kikay” Reyes-Tolentino (1899-1983) publishes her research cowritten with Petrona Ramos titled Philippine Folk Dances and Games which is the first in a series of publications on Philippine folk dance.

media_caption: [National Artist Award] Leonor Orosa-Goquingco, 1976
text_description: Premiered at the Metropolitan Theater is Trend: Return to Native, a folkloric ballet in five parts choreographed by Leonor Orosa-Goquingco (in photo). (Photo from Steve Villaruz Collection)

media_caption: Carmen Rosales and Rogelio dela Rosa in Maalala Mo Kaya, 1954
text_description: The stage show maintains its popularity. To celebrate the end of the Japanese occupation, Salvador stages a grand show at the Apollo for 40 days featuring big stars Carmen Rosales and Rogelio de la Rosa (pictured). (Photo from Cesar Hernando Collection)
Dance scholars, choreographers, and educators are granted Fulbright scholarships: Francisca Reyes-Aquino, Rosalia Merino-Santos, Paz Cielo Belmonte, among others.

media_caption: Nida Blanca and Nestor de Villa dancing the boogie in Tumbalik na Daigdig, LVN Pictures, 1953
article_title: Dance 1950 Films with music and dances
text_description: Films with music and dances, mostly pop and folkloric choreographies, are popular in the 1950s, featuring dancing stars like Pancho Magalona, Tita Duran, Dolphy, Bayani Casimiro, and Nida Blanca and Nestor de Villa (in photo). (Photo from Simon Santos/Video 48)
Francisca Reyes-Aquino publishes the first of her six-volume Philippine Folk Dances (in photo) which will be used in the physical education classes all over the country.

media_caption: Lucrecia Reyes-Urtula’s Singkil by the Bayanihan Philippine Dance Company, ca 1970
text_description: Singkil, a folk dance choreography by Lucrecia Reyes-Urtula (1929-99), and music by Lucrecia R. Kasilag (1918-2008), is premiered by Bayanihan Philippine Dance Company in 1957 in Manila with lead dancer Henrietta Hofer as Princess. (Photo from Bayanihan Dance Company Collection)

media_caption: Original members of the Leyte Kalipayan Dance Company with founder Teresita Veloso-Pil on tour in the United States, 1965
text_description: The Leyte Kalipayan Dance Company (LKCD) with Teresita Veloso-Pil as artistic director performs all over the country. (Photo from Leyte Kalipayan Dance Company)

media_caption: Alice Reyes
text_description: Alice Reyes’s concert is presented at CCP, leading to the CCP Summer Workshop and the establishment of the CCP Dance Company. (Photo from Ballet Philippines)

media_caption: Ati-Atihan in Kalibo, Aklan, 2014
text_description: In Kalibo, Aklan, the Ati-atihan, a precolonial tradition, is transformed into a Filipino version of the Mardi Gras with weeklong events and dancers dressed up in exaggerated or exotic costumes and fantastic makeup. Photo: Ati-Atihan in Kalibo, Aklan, 2014 (Emil Marañon III).
Moriones, a Lenten street play, becomes an annual touristic festival in Boac, Marinduque.

media_caption: Greg Sta. Ines, left, and Jonathan Romulo in PETA’s May-i, May-i, Dulaang Rajah Sulayman, Manila, 1979
text_description: The Philippine Educational Theater Association presents the full-length May-i, May-i with choreography by Ligaya Amilbangsa about ancient Manila under the reign of Muslim leader Raha Sulayman from a scenario by Emman Lacaba, at Fort Santiago. (Photo from Nicanor G. Tiongson Collection)

media_caption: Macli-ing Dulag, Kalinga chieftain killed for leading the protest against the construction of dams.
text_description: Macli-ing Dulag's death occasions massive protests. It will be commemorated as Cordillera day in the succeeding years, celebrated with Cordillera dances.(Photo by Lin Neumann)

media_caption: Sinulog Festival in 2015.
text_description: In Cebu, the sinulog is transformed into a festival with grand parades as conceived by a regional official of the office of youth and sports. Photo: Sinulog Festival in 2015. (Teddy Uy)

media_caption: PETA’s Nukleyar, Dulaang Rajah Sulayman, Manila, 1983
media_credit: Photo by William B. Tan, PETA Library and Archives
text_description: Issue-oriented plays with anti-dictatorship themes are produced by PETA, such as Nukleyar I (in photo) and Oratoryo ng Bayan, choreographed with eclectic body movements. (Photo by William B. Tan, PETA Library and Archives)

media_caption: Subli dancers
text_description: CCP launches Elena Rivera Mirano’s Subli: One Dance in Four Voices, which gives a multisided perspective on the traditional dance of Batangas. (Photo by Neal Oshima)

media_caption: Alice Reyes, 2014
text_description: Alice Reyes receives the Gawad CCP para sa Sining. (Photo from Ballet Philippines Collection)

media_caption: Dance adaptation of the Panay epic, Hinilawod, by Dagyaw Theater and Dance Company
text_description: The Dagyaw Theater and Dance Company of Iloilo High School performs Hinilawod at the First CCP National Theater Festival, choreographed by Agnes Locsin in collaboration with Edwin C. Duero. (Photo from NCCA)
In Mindanao, the Kahayag Community Dance and Theater Company performs its most acclaimed and popular work, Tudbulul, a narrative dance that interprets the Tboli’s great epic.

media_caption: Bayanihan Philippine National Folk Dance Company performing the tinikling in Pulso Filipinas Filipino Dance Gala 2018, CCP Main Theater.
text_description: Bayanihan is declared the National Folk Dance Company of the Philippines. (Photo by Laurence Catalan)

media_caption: 2000 Gawad Manlilikha ng Bayan (GAMABA) awardee Alonzo Saclag
text_description: Alonzo Saclag, Kalinga musician and dancer who founded the Kalinga Budong Dance Troupe, is proclaimed as Gawad Manlilikha ng Bayan. (Photo from NCCA)

media_caption: Ballet Center Cebu's Swan Lake, 2015
text_description: Cebu Ballet Center is renamed Ballet Center Cebu under Nicolas Pacaña and Gregory Aaron, in recognition of its founding by Fe Sala-Villarica in 1951. Photo: Ballet Center Cebu's Swan Lake, 2015 (Ballet Center Cebu Collection)
